reviewText:
Okay so...

Pros:
Good graphics, an interesting concept

Cons:
It's literally just a short demo using the Cryengine with borrowed stock music and sound effects.
The music" (basically Enya) is annoyingly loud and cannot be turned off or even down.
There is also no control setup.
You are limited to walking

reviewText: This is a walking simulator and I knew that from the start. I usually enjoy them from time to time. This game on the other hand offers really nothing. You start at one point and end at another. There is no dialoge in the game so all you are doing is walking through the woods listening to the same 30 second song over and over again. It would have been nice to have had some interaction with the world as well. Being able to open some doors and look around at the cool looking buildings. But all you can do is wave at the buildings and walk on by. The game is only 5 bucks but I really can't recommend this game at all.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sxB6oftruXo

reviewText: This isn't a game, and doesn't go for very long. The scenery is beautiful however, and it's a relaxing atmosphere. There is a slowed down effect throughout the entire experience, which does have a certain charm to it, but that gets old after a time, especially if you want to rush over to explore a building - which you will only be able to explore to outside of. None of the buildings you can enter. Relaxing music is played, which is nice, but noticably repetitive after a time. You can choose for it to be set in Summer or Winter, but that makes little different. Only get this if it's on sale, and you just want to slowly walk through some outdoor scenary.

reviewText:
A nice experience, but the game's rough around the edges.

This casual exploration game was also tagged as being an action, adventure and simulation game, and that might give readers the wrong idea. Although there's a hint of adventure, there is little action or simulation to be found in The Lost Valley. You basically walk around and discover the scenery.

Call it The Vanishing of Ethan Carter minus the gameplay.

It makes for a very light-hearted experience, which I personally quite enjoyed. If a relaxing 30 minute playthrough without much goals or gameplay sounds appealing to you, then I think you'll find you'll like it. If it doesn't, The Lost Valley won't be able to hold your attention for too long.

First off, the game really thrives on the Cryengine. The graphics are wonderfully vivid and the physics are impressive. Most plants move elegantly in the wind and are pushed aside when you walk through them. The animations and models used for the various animals look lively and shadows look nice as well.

The game really allows you to immerse into its world, but from time to time you'll find yourself uncomfortably drawn back to reality by the unpolished side of The Lost Valley.

The developers use invisible walls to prevent the player from straying too far from the intended path.

Sound produced by waterfalls starts and stops abruptly instead of fading in and out as you move.

There's a bunch of visual quirks, such as puddles of water that show circles from rain drops when it's not raining and tree branches that move through solid objects.

The player itself is also poorly animated. You can often walk on water and when you're moving through shallow waters, your arms will make swimming motions above the water. The player's shadow also looks kind of weird when you're walking.

Most importantly, the speed at which you walk is frustratingly slow, and there's no option to run.


The game is quite enjoyable despite of issues like these, but it could easily be improved. As such it feels like a late beta: in good shape technically, but still in need of some serious player feedback. Let's hope the developers find the resources to put out a couple of paches and polish this into what it could be.

At the moment, The Lost Valley is fun for a single playthrough, solo or with friends. And it's fairly priced.

reviewText:
I have troubles running this game just because my monitor's native resolution is NOT 16:9 but 16:10 (1680*1050).

If I let all the DSR ratios in my Nvidia's control panel activated (something that any other game have no problem with), then the game menus won't work as expected (something like using a bigger virtual screen than my native monitor's resolution but only able to see the upper/left quarter), to the point I can't really do anything. Once all DSR ratios were desactivated the game menu navigation was fixed... until I forced vsync to be disabled in my Nvidia's control pannel, because now I'm going back to the first problem...

So, unless you have a 16:9 **NATIVE** monitor's resolution, I can't recommand this game in its actual state. Too bad, because the few minutes I managed to play it was looking *really* beautiful.

I hope a patch to fix the screen resolution issue will come.

reviewText:
THE GOOD:
-beautiful ambiance, both visually and music wise
-remains in first person view, without any distracting information on screen, great for escape into nature
-great concept, a theraputic, relaxing game

THE BAD:
-no audio tweaking options / volume cannot be raised/lowered / music cannot be turned off (the music is wonderful, and I could listen to it for hours, but the option to turn it off would have been nice nevertheless)
-the audio shuts off after a few hours (most won't play for hours at a time, so it's a non-issue for the majority of gamers)

VERDICT: If you want to relax and enjoy a beautiful natural ambiance, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
If you like Walking Simulators, play this one before Drizzlepath, this is a fine map arguably better than Drizzlepath's but having played both, I can't help but feel that this is really Drizzlepath without a story; the character walks in the same way, but seems to jump in a less responsive way, the terrain when you go off the path seems to be more sticky than Drizzlepath & both games have the odd 'suddenly you can hear the rain & just as quickly the sound effect turns off again' which might be to do with the engine, I don't know.

I still enjoyed it, I'll play it through again in winter mode; if it had a story in the game it would be quite a good game, but i only remembered the premise of the character being an injured cyclist looking for a boat when I read another review about what the point of that being in the blurb when the game doesn't elude to it at all.

Bought it for 10% off, but I would have been comfortable with the normal $5 price, i like walking simulators & hope if there is a next effort that it has a story to go with a beautiful map.

reviewText:
My The Lost Vally Experiance
TL:DR

A stunning graphical project for Â£4, A tech demo really but a detailed and enjoyable experiance.

Full Review
To start off i dont normally make reviews but i felt i needed to in with this demo so please bare with my on this one.

The Lost Valley in all of its amazing detail graphically is at heart only a playable tech demo, When we enter the Demo for the first time we are presented with a great setting of an idyllic forest where everything seems to be in harmony.

For the first couple of minuets of this game you are put into a sence of calm and you are left to take in the surroundings and the atmospheric scene that is left before you. This however does not last very long.

The first thing that hits you when you start to take your walk is the lack of ambiant sound effects, While yes there are some in the game they seem to only be triggered at certain points, The walking should be a constant sound effect, But i only heard it a couple of times throughout the whole demo. There was no wind brushing though the trees, There was no wildlife or sounds of water when walking through the ponds. All these things while easy to place into the game should i fell have been there thoughout rather than just at triggered moments in the demo.

The next thing to mention is the soundtrack used in the demo, It is awful the first couple of minuets the sound track is the one used in the trailer which in my opinion i was all for i love that type of harmonic music, It all went down hill when that track had finished, It was then replaced by what i can only describe as somone mashing random keys on a piano it was grating and the game lost all of its idyllic setting, I found myself wanting to get to the end alot quicker.

Graphically i cannot fault the demo ,Cryengine is one of if not the best engine on the market at the moment, With it's easy to use machanics and high levle of quality cryengine was an ideal choice for this type of demo. Some things for the devs though, I have worked with cryengine in the past and i noticed the in-game CC was not locked, I was messing around with some commands and while most of the settings where ideal for the experiance there where things like, Level of Detail, Particles, Image Post-Processing and Fps Cap i found myself changing to give a better visual experiance.

As far as the actually game play is concerned the is not much to it you walk crouch and jump, While crouching and jumping are in the Demo there is no real need for them to be used as the whole Demo can be finished without them, While walking around there is only one point i found myself walking off the track to a building, one thing that would of been a nice thing to add is the ability for explore even if it was to the point of entering buildings or multiple paths to give the Demo some reply value.

All in all i did enjoy the experiance, If they would remove the piano soundtrack and add the things i mentioned in the review it would complete this game. For Â£4 i would reccommend this while short in lenght it is a well designed concept of what Cryengine can do.

reviewText:
Ingredients:
4 skinless, boneless chicken breasts
4 thick slices Jarlsberg cheese
1 egg, beaten
1 cup dried bread crumbs
3 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley
1 clove garlic, chopped
2 tablespoons olive oil
1 (14.5 ounce) can chicken broth

1. Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).

2. Pound the chicken breasts to about 1/8 inch thickness. In a shallow plate or bowl, mix together the bread crumbs and parsley. Place a slice of cheese on each breast, roll up tightly, then dip into the egg and then the bread crumb mixture. (Note: Hold roll closed; after dipping, you will see that it begins to stay together).

3. In a large skillet, saute garlic in olive oil. Add roll ups and brown quickly, just enough for the chicken to have a crisp outer coating. Remove roll ups from skillet and drain on paper towels.

4. Pour 1/2 of the chicken broth into a 9x13 inch baking dish. Add all four roll ups. Bake uncovered in the preheated oven for 45 minutes, basting once with the remaining broth.
